qas.question: What is the name of the popular assembly in Sparta?
Apellon is derived from what Doric month?
What is offered at the initiation of young men during familly-festival apellai?
What Doric word originally meant wall or fence for animals?

context: The etymology of the name is uncertain. The spelling Ἀπόλλων (pronounced [a.pól.lɔːn] in Classical Attic) had almost superseded all other forms by the beginning of the common era, but the Doric form Apellon (Ἀπέλλων), is more archaic, derived from an earlier *Ἀπέλjων. It probably is a cognate to the Doric month <a1_0>Apellaios<a1_0/> (Ἀπελλαῖος), and the offerings <a2_0>apellaia<a2_0/> (ἀπελλαῖα) at the initiation of the young men during the family-festival apellai (ἀπέλλαι). According to some scholars the words are derived from the Doric word <a3_0>apella<a3_0/> (ἀπέλλα), which originally meant "wall," "fence for animals" and later "assembly within the limits of the square." <a0_0>Apella<a0_0/> (Ἀπέλλα) is the name of the popular assembly in Sparta, corresponding to the ecclesia (ἐκκλησία). R. S. P. Beekes rejected the connection of the theonym with the noun apellai and suggested a Pre-Greek proto-form *Apalyun.
